artHead: According to a meme, in 2003, when 3G was introduced to the world, there was an outbreak of Sars, or severe acute respiratory syndrome. In 2009, 4G was introduced and there was a swine flu outbreak, and in 2020, when 5G was introduced, the world has suffered the coronavirus outbreak.
exp: Various authorities, including the World Health Organization, have been clear that viruses cannot travel on radio waves or mobile networks. Two Nigerian computer scientist experts also confirmed that here is no link between 5G and COVID-19.
articleContent:
No, disease outbreaks ‚Äì including coronavirus ‚Äì not caused by 3G, 4G or 5G
10:58 | 20th April 2020 (GMT)
A message shared on WhatsApp suggests a link between the introduction of wireless network technologies and outbreaks of diseases.¬†
It says that in 2003, when 3G was introduced to the world, there was an outbreak of Sars, or severe acute respiratory syndrome. In 2009, 4G was introduced and there was a swine flu outbreak, and in 2020, when 5G was introduced, the world has suffered the coronavirus outbreak.
The claim has also been shared on Facebook. Similar claims connecting Covid-19 and 5G have been posted many times across Facebook since the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic .¬†
But is there any connection between the introduction of 3G, 4G and 5G, and disease?¬†
3G, 4G and 5G
The ‚ÄúG‚Äù in all three names refers to which ‚Äúgeneration‚Äù of cellular technology it is. In essence, mobile phone communications become faster with every development, and more data can be sent from phone to phone.¬†
The introduction of 3G in 2001 saw the birth of the smartphone. Before 3G, cell phones could only send text messages and voice calls. But with 3G ‚Äúcommunication takes place at bit-rates high enough for sending and receiving photographs, video clips, music files, emails, and more‚Äù, according to Britannica .¬†
As early as 2005, 4G was available in South Korea, being rolled out in several European countries over the next few years. It was launched in the US in 2009.
The next generation of mobile internet connection is 5G, providing even faster data download and upload speeds.
According to the BBC , 5G could achieve browsing and download speeds about 10 to 20 times faster than 4G. But it‚Äôs only gradually being rolled out in big cities across the world. Most nodes are in Switzerland, South Korea, Kuwait, the US and the UK.¬†
Sars, swine flu and Covid-19
The first disease mentioned in the viral message is also a coronavirus. These are a group of viruses that cause illnesses ranging from the common cold to more serious diseases.¬†
The severe acute respiratory syndrome, or Sars, coronavirus was identified in 2003 . It first infected humans in the Guangdong province of southern China in 2002. A Sars epidemic affected 26 countries and resulted in more than 8,000 cases in 2003.¬†
Swine flu or H1N1 was responsible for a global influenza outbreak in 2009 and 2010. The virus was first identified in Mexico in April 2009, and became known as swine flu because it was similar to flu viruses that affect pigs.
An outbreak of the new coronavirus was identified in Wuhan , China in late December 2019. The technical name of the virus is severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 , or Sars-CoV-2. It causes the disease Covid-19 , and was declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization on 11 March 2020.¬†
No link between mobile networks and viruses
The WHO has been clear that viruses cannot travel on radio waves or mobile networks.
‚ÄúCovid-19 is spreading in many countries that do not have 5G mobile networks,‚Äù it says . ‚ÄúCovid-19 is spread through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs, sneezes or speaks. People can also be infected by touching a contaminated surface and then their eyes, mouth or nose.‚Äù
Experts‚Äô reactions
Godspower Ekuobase, a professor of computer science at the University of Benin in southern Nigeria, told Africa Check there is no correlation between 5G and Covid-19.
‚ÄúWhy would people even think 5G caused Covid-19?‚Äù he asked. ‚ÄúIt is like saying hot iron causes malaria ‚Äì it sounds absurd. Nigeria hasn‚Äôt even fully deployed 4G, not to mention 5G, and yet we are battling with the Covid-19 pandemic.
‚ÄúResearch is ongoing and technology is improving. It is for our own good that we accept an improved form of technology rather than make false claims about it. 5G is an improvement over 4G.‚Äù
Samuel Okolie, a professor of computer science at Babcock University in southwestern Nigeria, also said there is no link between 5G and Covid-19.¬†
‚ÄúI think these are two distinct issues which people are mixing up and getting themselves confused. There is no link between 5G and coronavirus. People should stick to what agencies such as Nigeria Centre for Disease Control and Nigeria Communications Commission publish on their websites. 5G doesn‚Äôt cause Covid-19.‚Äù
Nigerian ministry debunks claim
Nigeria‚Äôs federal government has also addressed ‚Äúthe public concern about the health implications of the deployment of Fifth Generation Mobile Networks‚Äù and debunked claims that 5G is connected to Covid-19.¬†
The minister of communications and digital economy , Isa Ali Pantami, said no licence had been issued for the deployment of 5G in Nigeria.
He added that the trial for the 5G network had run for a period of three months starting 25 November 2019, to critically review the implications of deploying 5G in Nigeria, and that this reporting process was ongoing.¬†
¬†‚ÄúThe National Frequency Management Council, of which I am the chairman, has not deliberated on or released any bulk frequency spectrum for the deployment of 5G,‚Äù Pantami said.
Other agencies rate claim false
The Nigerian Communications Commission and telecoms operators have also condemned claims that 5G is causing Covid-19 in Nigeria. The agencies called on Nigerians to disregard the information .
On 5 April, the National Orientation Agency , which ensures government policies are better understood by the general public, also released a statement debunking the claim.
‚ÄúSocial media is awash with messages that suggest 5G telecom masts may be responsible for #COVID19 outbreak in countries where service has been launched. @NigeriaGov has not issued a 5G operational license yet. No scientific evidence linking 5G network to #COVID19,‚Äù it said. ‚Äì Motunrayo Joel
¬†
For publishers: what to do if your post is rated false
A fact-checker has rated your Facebook or Instagram post as ‚Äúfalse‚Äù. What should you do? First, don't delete!
Click on our guide for the steps you should follow.

artHead: President Donald Trump said former President Obama funded the coronavirus that was creatical in biological Wuhan lab.
exp: Trump made no such announcements, only that allegations of grants to the lab were being studied by his administration.
articleContent:
Fact Check: Trump Did NOT Announce The 'Biological' lab In Wuhan Was 'Funded' By Obama
Hoax Alert
STORY UPDATED: check for updates below .
Not exactly
Did President Trump announce that the "biological" lab in Wuhan where the "COVID-19 virus was created" was "funded" by President Barack Hussein Obama? No, that's not true. Trump said the allegations were being studied by his administration, but he made no such announcement. Still, many on the right have spread misleading and false social media posts making the claim.
Trump was asked at a recent White House coronavirus daily briefing about a news report by the Daily Mail that said the U.S. National Institues of Health awarded a $3.7 million research grant to the Wuhan Institute of Virology .
Many on social media jumped on the moment. The viral posts generally were like this one on Facebook (archived here ) where it was published on April 20, 2020. The full text of the post read:
BREAKING NEWS: ARE YOU SITTING DOWN??? PRESIDENT TRUMP JUST ANNOUNCED THAT THE "BIOLOGICAL" LAB IN WUHAN WHERE THE COVID-19 VIRUS WAS CREATED WAS "FUNDED" BY PRESIDENT BARAK HUSSEIN OBAMA IN 2015 TO THE TUNE OF $3,800,000 AMERICAN DOLLARS!!! THIS FACT DIRECTLY LINKS OBAMA TO ALL 150,000 DEATHS AROUND THE WORLD! BTW, THIS SAME OBAMA JUST ENDORSED CREEPY JOE BIDEN FOR THE PRESIDENCY! FOLKS, YOU CAN'T MAKE THIS STUFF UP!"
This is what the post looked like on Facebook at the time of writing:
Some on social media questioned the sourcing.
Here was the full exchange during the White House briefing on April 17, 2020, when reporter Newsmax Media's Emerald Robinson asked the president about a Daily Mail story story on the $3.7 million grant.
"Why would the U.S. give a grant like that to China?" Robinson asked.
The Obama administration gave them a grant of $3.7 million?" Trump asked in response, according to the official White House transcript . "I've been hearing about that. And we've instructed that if any grants are going to that area -- we're looking at it, literally, about an hour ago, and also early in the morning. We will end that grant very quickly.
"But it was granted quite a while ago. They were granted a substantial amount of money. We're going to look at it and take a look. But I understand it was a number of years ago, right?"
Trump then asked what year the grant was made -- The reporter answered: "2015." Trump then pondered: "Who was President then? I wonder."
Below is a YouTube video with a suggestive title connecting the payment to the Obama administation. It's of the April 17, 2020, exchange, posted by ProductiehuisEU -- an audiovisual and editorial production company based in Belgium -- under the title "Trump wants to stop Wuhan lab funding, Obama's NIH sent $3.7M to lab coronavirus may have originated."
The description of the video is "The Obama-Biden Administration reportedly gave $3.7 million to the Chinese lab in Wuhan that is the subject of the investigation into the origin of the coronavirus."
But here is the C-SPAN video of the full briefing from the same day, simply titled "President Trump with Coronavirus Task Force Briefing: President Trump and members of the White House Coronavirus Task Force held a briefing on the federal government's response to the pandemic."
The Wuhan Institute of Virology, which has studied bat-borne coronaviruses and handles other deadly pathogens in its most secure Biosafety Level 4 lab, has come under scrutiny amid speculation the deadly COVID-19 pandemic originated from the labaoratory and not the wet market in the Chinese city of Wuhan.
The Wall Street Journal in early March reported that a DNA specialist, Botao Xiao of South China University of Technology, published a paper stating "the killer coronavirus probably originated from a laboratory in Wuhan." Xiao told The Wall Street Journal he had since withdrawn his paper.
China has denied the pandemic originated from the lab. But the scrutiny has only intensified with Republican lawmakers in Washingon demanding more answers.
At the April 17 briefing, Trump was asked about an investigation "into whether the virus escaped" from the Wuhan lab.
Well, we're looking at that. A lot of people are looking at it. It seems to make sense. They talk about a certain kind of bat, but that bat wasn't in that area. If you can believe this, that's what they're down to now, is bats. But that bat is not in that area. That bat wasn't sold at that wet zone. It wasn't sold there. That bat is 40 miles away. So a lot of strange things are happening, but there is a lot of investigation going on and we're going to find out.
All I can say is, wherever it came from -- it came from China -- in whatever form, 184 countries now are suffering because of it. And it's too bad, isn't it?
On its website , the Wuhan Institute of Virology lists more than two dozen international partners, including the U.S. National Institutes of Health. Other international partners include the University of Alabama, University of North Texas, the EcoHealth Alliance, Harvard University and the National Wildlife Federation.
A spokesman for the National Wildlife Federation told Lead Stories that group has never had a relationship with the lab and has recently asked the lab to remove the group's name from its website:
We have never had a partnership with this lab, so it is hard to know why we ended up on this list.
The NIH lists an array of research with Wuhan here , including some during the Trump adminisitration. One program from 2017 was called the "Biosafety Level 4 Laboratory User Training Program" and aimed to train people to work in the biocontainment lab: "Developing an appropriate and rigorous BSL-4 laboratory user training system is an essential prerequisite for ensuring the safety of laboratory workers, operations, and the environment."
18 days
ago 19:24
Update 7aPT, Monday, April 27, 2020 -- adding comment from National Wildlife Federation denying connection to lab
Lead Stories is working with the CoronaVirusFacts/DatosCoronaVirus Alliance, a coalition of more than 100 fact-checkers who are fighting misinformation related to the COVID-19 pandemic. Learn more about the alliance here .
Wayne Drash, a staff writer and fact-checker for Lead Stories, is a former senior producer and writer for CNN‚Äôs Health team, telling narratives about life and the unfolding drama of the world we live on. He specialized in covering complex major issues, such as health insurance, the opioid epidemic and Big Pharma.
¬†

artHead: Madrid‚Äôs city council has made it compulsory to be registered in the city in order to access the IFEMA pavilion for the homeless.
exp: Both the 'Hogar S√≠' foundation and the City Hall of Madrid explain that they do ask homeless people if they are registered "in Madrid or elsewhere", but that "this has never been a requirement".
articleContent:
El Ayuntamiento de Madrid no ha puesto como requisito estar empadronado en la capital para acceder al pabell√≥n de IFEMA para personas sin hogar
Siguiente
El Ayuntamiento de Madrid no ha puesto como requisito estar empadronado en la capital para acceder al pabell√≥n de IFEMA para personas sin hogar
Tanto la fundaci√≥n Hogar S√≠ como la Alcald√≠a de Madrid explican que s√≠ se pregunta a las personas sin hogar si est√°n empadronadas ‚Äúen Madrid o en otro lugar‚Äù, pero que ‚Äúnunca ha sido un requisito‚Äù.
sin hogar
Nos hab√©is preguntado a trav√©s de nuestro servicio de verificaci√≥n de WhastApp y redes sociales por una imagen que muestra un gran grupo de camas vac√≠as de uno de los pabellones de IFEMA habilitados para las personas sin hogar por el COVID-19. Esta va acompa√±ada de un mensaje que indica que el Alcalde de Madrid ‚Äúpuso a los sin techo‚Äù la condici√≥n de ‚Äúestar empadronados‚Äù para poder acceder. Esto es FALSO.
La fotograf√≠a fue tomada en los d√≠as previos a la apertura del pabell√≥n y, tal y como confirma a Newtral.es el jefe de prensa del √°rea de Familias, Igualdad y Bienestar Social de la Alcald√≠a de Madrid, estar empadronado en la capital ‚Äúnunca ha sido un requisito‚Äù.¬†
De igual forma desde la fundaci√≥n contra la exclusi√≥n social de las personas en situaci√≥n de sinhogarismo, Hogar S√≠, confirman a Newtral.es que no les consta que el Ayuntamiento ‚Äúrequiriera el empadronamiento para acceder‚Äù. Pero lamentan que estar empadronado es todav√≠a un ‚Äúobst√°culo‚Äù para acceder a los servicios sociales y de vivienda, como la Renta M√≠nima de Inserci√≥n, ‚Äútodos y cada uno de los d√≠as, no s√≥lo en tiempos de pandemia‚Äù.
La imagen que acompa√±a a este mensaje fue publicada en un art√≠culo del El Salto el 21 de marzo de 2020 con el pie de ‚ÄúEl Samur Social y la UME han comenzado la habilitaci√≥n del pabell√≥n de Ifema para personas sin hogar con motivo de la crisis COVID-19‚Äù. Sin embargo, esta fue tomada d√≠as antes de su apertura, el 18 de marzo, por el fot√≥grafo David F. Sabadell.¬†
Desde la Alcald√≠a confirman que en la entrada al pabell√≥n s√≠ se pregunt√≥ a las personas si estaban o no empadronadas en Madrid, pero como ‚Äúparte de la rutina del trabajo social con las personas sin hogar‚Äù. No es una condici√≥n para acceder: ‚Äúnunca ha sido un requisito ni lo es ahora‚Äù. De hecho, seg√∫n indican, se les ofrece que se empadronen ‚Äúen centros de servicios sociales o en la misma sede central del SAMUR social‚Äù.¬†
Seg√∫n datos aportados por la fundaci√≥n Hogar S√≠, en Espa√±a hay entre 31.000 y 35.000 personas sin hogar . M√°s de 3.000 personas solo en Madrid, aunque ‚Äúpodr√≠an ser m√°s‚Äù. Y el hecho del car√°cter temporal de las plazas de albergues o polideportivos de ayuda, como este pabell√≥n. Y aunque demuestran el esfuerzo de la administraci√≥n por adaptarse a la emergencia, conceden, tambi√©n demuestran las ‚Äúcarencias del sistema de atenci√≥n a personas sin hogar‚Äù. No s√≥lo del Ayuntamiento de Madrid, sino generalizadas en todo el pa√≠s. Por ello desde Hogar S√≠ indican que es el momento de que nos replanteemos el sistema de atenci√≥n a personas en situaci√≥n de sinhogarismo ‚Äúde arriba a abajo‚Äù.¬†
De este modo indican que el foco deber√≠a estar en si los modelos de alojamiento temporal son ‚Äúel adecuado para solucionar el sinhogarismo‚Äù y si es razonable que, todas las noches, al menos 8.000 personas en nuestro pa√≠s vivan en la calle‚Äù. Desde la Fundaci√≥n creen que respecto a la respuesta del Ayuntamiento ‚Äúencajan mucho mejor‚Äù las 120 plazas de hotel para personas en esta situaci√≥n y con s√≠ntomas leves de coronavirus. Es decir, la apuesta por ‚Äúlas soluciones que no reproducen los modelos de alojamiento colectivo‚Äù.¬†
‚ÄúTodas las semanas mueren en nuestro pa√≠s personas en situaci√≥n de sinhogarismo, con pandemia o sin pandemia, con fr√≠o o con calor‚Äù.
Francisco Lores Mart√≠nez, T√©cnico de Comunicaci√≥n e Incidencia de Hogar S√≠
Frente a esta crisis, el Ayuntamiento de la capital tambi√©n habilit√≥ un hotel en Arganda del Rey para 56 personas sin hogar y solicitantes de asilo y otras 40 plazas en una pensi√≥n. A esto se le sum√≥ el pabell√≥n de la Feria de Madrid de la imagen con 150 plazas que, de hecho, se llen√≥ ‚Äúal segundo o tercer d√≠a‚Äù, y en previsi√≥n de este hecho, ‚Äúse abri√≥ el hospital de campa√±a‚Äù y ‚Äúel centro deportivo Samaranch, en Arganzuela‚Äù que tambi√©n tiene 150 plazas y en este momento tambi√©n ‚Äúest√° completo‚Äù.
Fuentes
Jefe de prensa del √°rea de Familias, Igualdad y Bienestar Social de la Alcald√≠a de Madrid
T√©cnico de Comunicaci√≥n e Incidencia de la fundaci√≥n Hogar S√≠¬†

artHead: On video an unidentified woman warns Africans not to accept vaccines from China, claiming that the Chinese government wants to kill the ‚ÄúAfrican population‚Äù with fake vaccines. She says that seven children died in Senegal after being given the fake vaccine from China.
exp: A man who was arrested in Senegal apparently did tell people he had a coronavirus vaccine, but he was actually selling traditional medicines and cosmetics. He was arrested for pretending to be a public agent in order to get into people‚Äôs homes. There are no reports from this incident of children being either injected or dying as a result of it. China has donated medical personal protective equipment to African countries. But the donated supplies did not include vaccines and, according to the World Health Organization, there is currently no vaccine for COVID-19.
articleContent:
No, seven children in Senegal weren‚Äôt killed by fake coronavirus vaccine
02:46 | 22nd April 2020 (GMT)
‚ÄúThis thing that has arrived in Africa has already killed seven children. It is not a vaccine for coronavirus,‚Äù says a woman in a video circulating on WhatsApp in South Africa. It is not clear when the video was made, but Africa Check received it on 20 April 2020.
The woman does not give her name or profession. In a 10-minute video, she warns Africans not to accept vaccines from China, claiming that the Chinese government wants to kill the ‚ÄúAfrican population‚Äù with fake vaccines. She claims that seven children died in Senegal after being given the fake vaccine.
‚ÄúThere is no vaccine. So whatever the hell they have sent to Africa, I believe Senegal if I‚Äôm correct, is not a vaccine for coronavirus,‚Äù she says.
A 26-minute version of the video was published on Facebook on 16 April.¬†
The Chinese government has sent medical supplies to help in the treatment of Covid-19 , to be distributed to 18 African countries , including Ghana and Senegal. The shipment arrived in Accra, Ghana on 6 April.
Did seven children in Senegal die after being injected with a fake coronavirus vaccine sent by the Chinese government? We checked.
Man arrested in Senegal was selling cosmetics and traditional medicines
Les Observateurs , an affiliate of France24 that investigates amateur videos and photographs, has fact-checked a French-language video circulating on Facebook. The video claimed to show a man in Senegal being arrested after injecting seven children with a Covid-19 vaccine. The children are claimed to have died on the spot. ¬†
Les Observateurs found the original Wolof-language version of the video. In the original, a voice says the man was arrested after claiming to have Covid-19 vaccines. It does not mention seven children dying.¬†
The fact-check says the incident took place in Pikine, Senegal on 26 March. A man wearing a T-shirt with a health department logo told people he had a coronavirus vaccine, but he was actually selling traditional medicines and cosmetics . He was arrested for pretending to be a public agent in order to get into people‚Äôs homes.¬†
A spokesperson for Senegal‚Äôs health department confirmed most of these details to the AFP , but said the man ‚Äúnever wanted to vaccinate people‚Äù.¬†
The spokesperson said : ‚ÄúHe was passing by a house, and the resident‚Äôs aunt started causing panic when she heard the word ‚Äòcoronavirus‚Äô. A crowd of people gathered outside, thinking this man wanted to vaccinate people by force.‚Äù
China sent medical equipment, not vaccines
We have previously fact-checked the claim that China has sent coronavirus vaccines to Africa and found it to be false.¬†
According to the Chinese embassy in Ghana , China donated medical personal protective equipment like N95 face masks , medical protective suits, goggles, gloves and temporal artery thermometers .
The donated supplies did not include vaccines and, according to the World Health Organization, there is currently no vaccine for Covid-19.¬†
There are 70 possible vaccines in clinical and preclinical evaluation. The first phases of human clinical trials are underway in the US , UK , and China . ‚Äì Naledi Mashishi
¬†
For publishers: what to do if your post is rated false
A fact-checker has rated your Facebook or Instagram post as ‚Äúfalse‚Äù. What should you do? First, don't delete!
Click on our guide for the steps you should follow.

artHead: ‚ÄúHundreds and hundreds of labs are ready, willing, and able.‚Äù
exp: The president said the White House has a list that shows many untapped labs are ready to go to do more testing. Labs exist, but how many are ready to handle the patient specimens sent to them is unknown.
articleContent:
By Jon Greenberg April 23, 2020
Donald Trump exaggerates number of untapped coronavirus testing labs
If Your Time is short
The president said the White House has a list that shows many untapped labs are ready to go to do more testing.
Labs exist, but how many are ready to handle the patient specimens sent to them is unknown.
See the sources for this fact-check
At a coronavirus press conference, President Donald Trump said he has a newly assembled list of labs across the country that have the equipment needed to conduct tests for the novel coronavirus.¬†
"We provided each governor with a list of the names, addresses, and phone numbers of the labs where they can find additional testing capacity within their states ‚Äî many, many labs," Trump told reporters April 20 . "We‚Äôre providing you with the list. We‚Äôll show it to you now if you need it. We‚Äôll give you the details. But hundreds and hundreds of labs are ready, willing, and able."
Is there a vast, untapped reservoir of labs at the states‚Äô disposal?
Not in the way Trump described it. Many labs exist, but it‚Äôs not yet clear they have the capacity and equipment needed to do the job.
Trying to find the labs
We asked the White House for the data to back up Trump‚Äôs assertion about hundreds of labs, but the press office declined to comment and did not provide the list Trump referenced. A spokesperson for the Health and Human Services Department said it couldn‚Äôt provide a tally of these untapped labs.
The spokesperson there did point to the Food and Drug Administration, which lists 109 labs nationwide that are already offering COVID-19 testing. The FDA also has a separate list of labs that are processing tests under emergency authorization. That adds 18 for a total of 127.¬†
But Trump was describing labs that could conduct tests, not ones that already were.
White House press staff provided an image of a map that included any lab that had equipment for identifying the genetic sequence of a virus. The image quality was too low for counting each dot. But Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland, and chair of the National Governors Association, said that not only were many on the list already known to officials in his state, they had reached out to them before.
Credit: White House
¬†
"We‚Äôve been trying for over a month to get access to use labs, like at National Institutes of Health, with no success," Hogan said in an April 21 interview with MSNBC.
¬†
What makes a lab ‚Äòready‚Äô?
Even if the labs exist and are willing, it could be challenging to harness the capacity of new facilities identified by the White House in the anti-coronavirus fight.
Featured Fact-check
"This is COVID-19, not COVID-1, folks. And so you would think the people charged with the World Health Organization facts and figures would be on top of that."
By Bill McCarthy ‚Ä¢ April 15, 2020
That‚Äôs because all these labs are outfitted for the work they do in non-COVID scenarios, whether in defense, agriculture, basic research, or some other area. Each lab has testing equipment designed to meet those particular needs. Testing experts say it‚Äôs unrealistic to expect that each of these labs is able to analyze any specimen it receives.
"Just because the machine exists, you can't will it to work," said Scott Becker,¬† Association of Public Health Laboratories chief executive officer. "You can‚Äôt just show up with a sample, plug it in and expect it to work."
Louise Serio, spokeswoman for the American Clinical Laboratory Association, a trade group that includes the largest commercial labs, echoed the point that much depends on the kind of equipment ‚Äî or "platform" ‚Äî the lab has.
Test kits vary. They can contain different materials for a different range of steps in the process, and some are more complete than others. They are not interchangeable.
"For a lab to run a manufacturer‚Äôs test kit on a platform, the materials have to match up ‚Äî the test kit and the platform must be from the same manufacturer," Serio said.
Part of the challenge of using any lab is that testing is a three-step process.¬†
It starts by collecting the specimen with a swab, preserving it in a stable medium for transport, and doing all the data entry that clearly ties that particular specimen to the patient it came from.
At the lab, the RNA from the specimen is extracted and amplified so that it can be identified in a testing machine.¬†
Then the results are reviewed and shared with health care providers and public health departments.
The first two steps are vulnerable to supply shortages ‚Äî especially of the nasal swabs used to collect patient samples and the chemicals referred to as "reagents" that are needed to study them. States have been competing against each other and Washington for the same limited supply of essential goods, a situation that has become one of the primary constraints on testing in the U.S.
At the April 20 press conference, Vice President Mike Pence said a team at Walter Reed Medical Center was calling the labs on the list to see what they would need in order to help meet testing needs.
That outreach suggests that the government is still learning which labs are able to work with the states.
Our ruling
Trump said he had a list with hundreds and hundreds of labs "ready" and "able" to provide coronavirus testing. The White House declined to provide the list, and the Health and Human Services Department did not provide a tally.
The closest we found was a FDA list of about 130 labs nationwide.¬†
The people who work with testing said that simply possessing the laboratory equipment to process tests is insufficient to pull off the assignment. The vice president described how the government was still in the process of learning which labs could do what.
The labs exist, but the ready and able piece is a work in progress.
We rate this claim Mostly False.
Our Sources

artHead: There is a relationship between COVID-19 and the 5G network.
exp: The approaches that have been disseminated through the sociodigital and journalistic media about the responsibility of 5G telephone networks in the COVID-19 pandemic lack any scientific support to be credible or be considered as a line of investigation to mitigate it.
articleContent:
Falso que exista relaci√≥n entre COVID-19 y la red 5G
Ni los equipos de telefon√≠a m√≥vil causan c√°ncer ni las ondas que utilizan pueden transportar virus
¬†
Por Ginarely Valencia
Los planteamientos que se han difundido a trav√©s de medios sociodigitales y period√≠sticos sobre la responsabilidad de las redes de telefon√≠a 5G en la pandemia de COVID-19 carecen de cualquier sustento cient√≠fico para ser cre√≠bles o considerarse como una l√≠nea de investigaci√≥n para mitigarla.
Durante este mes de abril se report√≥ el ataque a antenas de telefon√≠a m√≥vil en Reino Unido (1) basados en la supuesta relaci√≥n entre la red 5G y la enfermedad que, a su vez, motivaron m√°s hip√≥tesis sin sustento sobre el contagio provocado por el virus SARS-CoV-2.
La aseveraci√≥n cobr√≥ fuerza despu√©s de que se hiciera viral un video en el que una persona identificada como el Dr. Thomas Cowan asegur√≥ que la propagaci√≥n de la enfermedad COVID-19 est√° relacionada con el 5G y que cada pandemia de la historia ha sido provocada por un ‚Äúsalto cu√°ntico¬ª en la electrificaci√≥n de la Tierra.
Las redes para telecomunicaci√≥n m√≥vil han sido continuamente asociadas con el incremento de algunas enfermedades como c√°ncer o diabetes y esa idea ha encontrado eco en las redes sociales, en personas famosas (2) de varios pa√≠ses y medios que las retoman sin evidencia alguna.
La supuesta base de esta asociaci√≥n deriva del da√±o que la radiaci√≥n puede generar a las c√©lulas y que resulta en debilidad del sistema inmunol√≥gico o el potencial desarrollo de c√°ncer.
Sin embargo, las radiofrecuencias que utilizan los sistemas cuyo servicio usamos de forma tan com√∫n en nuestra vida actual se encuentran en la baja frecuencia del espectro electromagn√©tico.
Es decir, pertenecen al rango de las radiaciones no ionizantes y carecen de relaci√≥n con el da√±o celular asociado a c√°ncer.
A su vez, las ionizantes, entre las que se encuentra la luz ultravioleta, los rayos X y la energ√≠a nuclear, en condiciones no controladas, pueden da√±ar m√∫ltiples procesos en las c√©lulas.
Qu√© dicen los especialistas
La propia Organizaci√≥n Mundial de la Salud¬†(3) ha asegurado que no hay evidencia de que las redes de telefon√≠a celular provoquen c√°ncer u otras enfermedades y han rechazado contundentemente el v√≠nculo entre la tecnolog√≠a 5G y la pandemia de COVID-19. (4)
Otro de los or√≠genes del mito que relaciona a la COVID-19 con esa tecnolog√≠a, es la guerra comercial entre Estados Unidos y China por el control del mercado de telecomunicaciones en el mundo y en la cual el llamado ‚Äúgigante asi√°tico‚Äù lleva la delantera.
Sobre el tema, el especialista en tecnolog√≠as de la informaci√≥n y comunicaci√≥n, Emilio Salda√±a, recuerda que cada ‚ÄúG‚Äù previa al nuevo sistema ha estado acompa√±ada de las mismas ideas de rechazo: amenaza a la salud, control mental, dominio tecnol√≥gico de la sociedad, espionaje entre naciones, entre otras.
En ese sentido, reconoce que mantener un ritmo de innovaci√≥n y de desarrollo tecnol√≥gico ha tra√≠do aparejado generalmente pr√°cticas como el espionaje industrial o robo de ideas, que han sido causa del recelo de empresas estadunidenses y del presidente de ese pa√≠s, Donald Trump al crecimiento de compa√±√≠as chinas de telefon√≠a m√≥vil como Huawei.
Lo que sucedi√≥, a√±ade tambi√©n, es que mientras en Estados Unidos la industria de la telefon√≠a m√≥vil y tecnolog√≠as en red se desarroll√≥ a un ritmo menor, la de China comenz√≥ a avanzar a mayor velocidad y a la fecha cuenta ya con infraestructura en los mercados europeos y contin√∫a su crecimiento hacia otros, lo que deja menor espacio de competencia a las estadunidenses.
A ese desplazamiento de mercado, se suma el temor del gobierno de Estados Unidos de que los equipos de origen chino que se vendan en su pa√≠s puedan adem√°s contener chips con los que se esp√≠e a sus ciudadanos o a sus instalaciones estrat√©gicas.
Estas preocupaciones, indic√≥, han servido como base para alimentar supuestas conspiraciones o sumarse a la informaci√≥n err√≥nea sobre el efecto de la radiaci√≥n no ionizante de los sistemas de telefon√≠a m√≥vil y que han llevado hasta la que hoy relaciona la pandemia con la red 5G.
A√±adi√≥ que un elemento que permite descartar totalmente la idea es que ning√∫n pa√≠s cuenta actualmente con la infraestructura en todo o la mayor√≠a de su territorio, es decir, el equipo de recepci√≥n y transmisi√≥n de se√±ales que se requiere para que la red 5G opere, al tiempo que existen muy pocos dispositivos personales en el mercado mundial que puedan aprovecharla
A su vez, en la revista cient√≠fica The Lancet (5), un grupo de 27 investigadores especializados en salud p√∫blica condenaron las ‚Äòteor√≠as de la conspiraci√≥n‚Äô que sugieren que la COVID-19 no tiene un origen natural aun frente a la evidencia cient√≠fica que demuestra la naturaleza del pat√≥geno.
Adem√°s, las ondas de radiofrecuencia no pueden generar, interactuar, ni transmitir virus de ninguna forma (6). Tampoco debilitan al cuerpo humano para hacerlo m√°s susceptible (7), ni son la fuente de enfermedades asociadas a la COVID-19.
Otro de los errores del mito es se√±alar directamente a China como el lugar de origen artificial del SARS-CoV-2: si la asociaci√≥n del 5G con la pandemia de COVID-19 fuera acertada, entonces el brote se hubiera registrado en Corea del Sur, que en junio de 2019 se convirti√≥ en el primer pa√≠s en incorporar esa tecnolog√≠a y que en dos meses super√≥ un mill√≥n de usuarios.
Edici√≥n: Luis R. Castrill√≥n
https://www.arpansa.gov.au/news/5g-and-other-telecommunications-do-not-affect-immune-system
#COVIDconCIENCIA es una iniciativa para cubrir la pandemia con base en evidencia cient√≠fica. Es una colaboraci√≥n entre Verificado, la Red Mexicana de Periodistas de Ciencia, El Editor de la Semana, Cient√≠ficas Mexicanas y La Bombilla.
Verificado es parte de la¬† Alianza #CoronaVirusFacts ¬†/ #DatosCoronaVirus, integrada por m√°s de 100 verificadores de datos de 70 pa√≠ses distintos que combatimos la desinformaci√≥n sobre la pandemia COVID-19. Este esfuerzo es encabezado por la International Fact Checking Network.
Tambi√©n integramos la red¬† LatamChequea Coronoavirus , un esfuerzo colaborativo de equipos verificadores de Am√©rica Latina y Espa√±a en tiempos de crisis sanitaria para combatir la infodemia.
¬øQu√© opinas?

artHead: Image of news channel claims Pakistan‚Äôs PM Imran Khan‚Äôs wife tested Covid-19 positive.
exp: This is a doctored image created on online graphic generator.

artHead: A photo shows what COVID-19 does in the throat.
exp: Injured throat photo does not show what the COVID-19 does. The image actually shows an infection with the MRSA bacteria and was shared in 2018.
articleContent:
Falso                     Falso                     Falso                     Falso                     Falso                     Falso                     Falso                     Falso
Falso
Foto de garganta con lesiones no muestra lo que hace el COVID-19
Por                                         Luisa Fernanda G√≥mez Cruz
La imagen realmente muestra una infecci√≥n por la bacteria MRSA y fue compartida en 2018.
Desde el 12 de abril circula por redes sociales una fotograf√≠a de lengua y garganta llena de heridas blancas con un texto que sostiene que ‚Äúesto es lo que hace el COVID-19 en la garganta y luego en los pulmones‚Äù.¬†
La imagen, sin embargo es falsa, pues tras hacer una b√∫squeda inversa de im√°genes en Google, encontramos que la imagen fue compartida originalmente en la red social Reddit el 29 de mayo de 2018; antes de que se hubiese desarrollado el virus SARS-CoV-2 que produce la enfermedad Covid-19.¬†
‚Äú¬øEs esta faringitis estreptoc√≥cica de aspecto normal? Muchas manchas blancas en las am√≠gdalas e incluso en la parte posterior de mi garganta‚Äù (Is this normal looking strep throat? Lots of white spots on tonsils and even on the back of my throat), pregunta el autor de la fotograf√≠a, (I_am_Trendy).¬†
M√°s tarde, el mismo autor de la imagen responde en un comentario: ‚ÄúGracias por la informaci√≥n. En realidad, hoy obtuve los resultados del cultivo. Maldito Mersa en la garganta‚Äù (Thanks for the info. Actually got the culture results back today. Fuckin Mersa in the throat!).
Jaime Castellanos, profesor de enfermedades infecciosas en la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, le dijo a Colombiacheck que, efectivamente, la imagen original muestra una amigdalitis o faringitis por un estafilococo aureus resistente a la meticilina (de donde viene el nombre de la MRSA, Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus). Es una de las bacterias m√°s complejas porque debe ser tratada con una serie de antibi√≥ticos diferente a los que se usan cl√°sicamente. ‚ÄúEs una pesadilla para los infect√≥logos‚Äù, dice Castellanos.¬†
La MRSA es una infecci√≥n frecuente en soldados, personas que est√°n en hospitales, personas que viven en hacinamiento o inmunosuprimidos. Y se produce por contacto muy cercano con personas contagiadas.
Castellanos aclara, adem√°s, que en general las infecciones virales (como la de Covid-19) no producen placas, pus, ni acumulaci√≥n como la que se ve en la garganta que muestra la foto. El coronavirus es una infecci√≥n que visualmente es dif√≠cil de captar porque no deja marcas; solo se muestra roja e hinchada.¬†
Aunque muchos pacientes de neumon√≠a por coronavirus tambi√©n terminan coinfectados por bacterias, en los hospitales se conocen muy bien y las neumon√≠as bacterianas se tratan con antibi√≥ticos. Las neumon√≠as por coronavirus u otros virus no tienen tratamiento directamente porque no hay medicamentos para los virus. De modo que es claro que la imagen no corresponde a una infecci√≥n por coronavirus, porque no genera da√±os en las am√≠gdalas o en la garganta como muestra la foto.
De modo que, como dijimos al comienzo, es falso que la fotograf√≠a muestre ‚Äúlo que hace el COVID-19 en la garganta‚Äù.
Art√≠culos relacionados
Verdadero                     Verdadero                     Verdadero                     Verdadero                     Verdadero                     Verdadero                     Verdadero                     Verdadero
Verdadero
Estados Unidos, Australia y China prueban vacunas contra el coronavirus (Covid-19)
Por Sania Salazar
Ante una emergencia como la actual los pasos para crear una vacuna pueden demorarse menos, pero no se pueden suprimir. Es poco factible que la vacuna contra el coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 se demore menos de 18 meses.
Una publicaci√≥n de Facebook asegura que Estados Unidos, Australia y China tienen vacunas contra el Coronavirus listas para ser probadas.¬†
Colombiacheck califica la afirmaci√≥n como verdadera ya que entidades de esos pa√≠ses anunciaron que est√°n empezando a probar en humanos tres posibles vacunas. Aunque esto es diferente a que est√©n listas para su uso masivo. Una experta explic√≥ que ante la gravedad del virus las fases para la producci√≥n de una vacuna pueden acortarse, pero aclar√≥ que no se pueden saltar los pasos.
Como lo contamos en otro chequeo , China anunci√≥ que empezar√° a probar en humanos una posible vacuna contra el virus SARS-CoV-2 (causante de la enfermedad Covid-19).¬†
En el caso de Estados Unidos la firma de biotecnolog√≠a Moderna anunci√≥ en su p√°gina web que empez√≥ a probar en humanos una posible vacuna. La Universidad de Queensland, en Australia, anunci√≥ tambi√©n a trav√©s de su p√°gina web que un equipo de investigadores tiene una posible vacuna, pero aclar√≥ que ‚Äúel grupo contin√∫a trabajando con un cronograma muy acelerado para mantenerse en el camino de las pruebas cl√≠nicas de investigaci√≥n despu√©s de mediados de a√±o‚Äù.
Sara Mar√≠a Robledo Restrepo, profesora titular de la facultad de medicina de la Universidad de Antioquia, coordinadora del comit√© central de √©tica de la misma universidad y directora de la Corporaci√≥n de Innovaci√≥n para el Desarrollo de Productos contra Enfermedades tropicales, Cidepro, le dijo a Colombiacheck que en t√©rminos normales el proceso para desarrollar una vacuna sigue las mismas fases que la producci√≥n de un medicamento, proceso que ya hab√≠amos explicado en Colombiacheck .
‚ÄúPor ser una enfermedad en la que tantas personas est√°n en riesgo y porque la probabilidad de complicaci√≥n y de muerte es tan alta a nivel global hay premura y por eso se acepta que se acorten los pasos, no que se eliminen. Por ejemplo, en este caso fue una fase muy r√°pida en modelos de rat√≥n para mirar que s√≠ se producen anticuerpos, entonces r√°pidamente se pasa a probarlo en humanos en pocos individuos y eso acelera el proceso. De todas maneras hay que hacer las siguientes fases‚Äù, explic√≥.
Robledo Restrepo indic√≥, adem√°s, que los permisos para aprobar los protocolos son un poco m√°s laxos en estos casos dada la gravedad de la situaci√≥n, as√≠ que asegur√≥ que es perfectamente factible que ya haya vacunas en desarrollo.
‚ÄúEn este momento hay muchas personas tratando de entender la enfermedad, que est√°n tratando de saber c√≥mo prevenir y c√≥mo inmunizar, por eso es que sale tanta informaci√≥n tan r√°pido, pero hay que tener cuidado con las fuentes de esa informaci√≥n‚Äù, asegur√≥.
La profesora record√≥, por √∫ltimo, que hay que continuar tomando todas las medidas de precauci√≥n porque aunque se est√° acelerando el proceso todav√≠a toma su tiempo y es prematuro afirmar que se logre¬† tener la vacuna antes de 18 meses.

artHead: Image of a critically ill COVID-19 infected woman hugging her child for the last time before her death.
exp: The image is an old incident and not related to any recent incident. It was found to exist on the internet at least since 1997.
articleContent:
Coronavirus , Coronavirus English , English , Fake News
¬†
An old image is being shared as ‚ÄòCOVID-19 infected woman hugged her child for the last time before death‚Äô
Twitter Facebook Reddit
An image of a woman with protective covering hugging a child is being shared on social media. The claim is that the woman is a critically-ill COVID-19 patient in Italy, and when she told the doctors of her final wish to hug her crying child, the doctors put a protective covering on her entire body and placed the child on her chest. Then the child at once stopped crying and the woman left the world. ‚ÄòFACTLY‚Äô has found the image to be old and not related to any recent incident. The image was found to exist on the internet at least since 1997. So, an old image is being shared in the context of COVID-19 outbreak.
Sources:

artHead: COVID-19, MERS and H1N1 epidemics coincide with the installation of 3G, 4G and 5G networks respectively.
exp: There is no link between the deployment of 3G, 4G or 5G and COVID-19. It's a conspiracy theory.
articleContent:
Epidemias de Covid-19, MERS e H1N1 coincidiram com instala√ß√£o de redes 5G, 4G e 3G respetivamente?
Partilhar
O que est√° em causa?
Em publica√ß√£o nas redes sociais apontam-se "factos e coincid√™ncias" no sentido de relacionar as epidemias de Covid-19 em 2019, MERS em 2012 e gripe A (H1N1) em 2009 com a suposta instala√ß√£o de antenas das redes 5G, 4G e 3G respetivamente. Mais, at√© a gripe asi√°tica da d√©cada de 1950 ter√° coincidido com o "in√≠cio de antenas de televis√£o na China". Verifica√ß√£o de factos.
¬© Ag√™ncia Lusa / EPA / Hotli Simanjuntak
De acordo com a publica√ß√£o em causa, a epidemia de Covid-19 ter√° coincidido com o "in√≠cio de antenas 5G", a MERS com o "in√≠cio de antenas 4G", a gripe A (H1N1) com o "in√≠cio de antenas 3G", a SARS com o "in√≠cio de antenas 2G", a gripe asi√°tica com o "in√≠cio de antenas de televis√£o na China" e a gripe espanhola com o "in√≠cio das antenas de r√°dio na Am√©rica e Europa".
V√°rios utilizadores do Facebook denunciaram este conte√∫do como sendo falso ou enganador.
Confirma-se?
Continuar a ler
¬†
Al√©m de n√£o encontrarmos qualquer ind√≠cio de sustenta√ß√£o factual ou validade cient√≠fica da propalada correla√ß√£o entre as referidas epidemias ou pandemias e a instala√ß√£o das referidas antenas de telecomunica√ß√µes, o facto √© que nem a suposta coincid√™ncia temporal, na maior parte dos casos, √© verdadeira.
Por exemplo, a instala√ß√£o da rede 4G come√ßou em dezembro de 2009, nas cidades de Oslo (Noruega) e Estocolmo (Su√©cia). No ano seguinte j√° estava em pleno funcionamento ¬†nos Estados Unidos da Am√©rica (EUA). O primeiro registo de infe√ß√£o pelo¬†coronav√≠rus da s√≠ndrome respirat√≥ria do M√©dio Oriente (MERS-CoV) data de 2012.
O mesmo se aplica √† instala√ß√£o da rede 3G que teve in√≠cio em 2001, utilizada primeiramente na Europa, Jap√£o e China. Em 2003 j√° tinha sido exponenciada √† escala global . Ora, a pandemia de¬†gripe A (H1N1) s√≥ ocorreu em 2009, quase uma d√©cada mais tarde.
Tal como o Pol√≠grafo j√° sinalizou recentemente, a suposta liga√ß√£o entre o novo coronav√≠rus e a instala√ß√£o da rede de telecomunica√ß√µes 5G n√£o passa de uma teoria de conspira√ß√£o infundada. A qual¬†j√° foi refutada por v√°rios cientistas, tais como¬†Simon Clarke, professor de microbiologia celular na Universidade de Reading, Reino Unido, que em declara√ß√µes √† BBC ¬†garantiu que a rede 5G ou as ondas de r√°dio e electromagn√©ticas n√£o afetam o sistema imunit√°rio dos humanos (outra variante muito propalada desta teoria de conspira√ß√£o).
"A presente epidemia √© causada por um v√≠rus que √© transmitido de uma pessoa infetada para outra. N√≥s sabemos que isto √© verdade. N√≥s at√© temos o v√≠rus a crescer no nosso laborat√≥rio, obtido a partir de uma pessoa com a doen√ßa. Os v√≠rus e as ondas electromagn√©ticas que fazem funcionar os telem√≥veis e as liga√ß√µes √† Internet s√£o coisas diferentes. T√£o diferentes quanto giz e queijo", explicou Simon Clarke.
N√£o obstante, algumas esta√ß√µes¬†da rede 5G em postes telef√≥nicos t√™m sido destru√≠das no Reino Unido. As autoridades indicam que esses ataques s√£o motivados pelas teorias de conspira√ß√£o em torno da tecnologia 5G que circulam nas redes sociais. Ali√°s, o mayor de Liverpool, Joe Anderson, revelou ter recebido amea√ßas por causa da instala√ß√£o da rede 5G na cidade.
Embora ainda care√ßa de estudos mais aprofundados sobre potenciais efeitos a m√©dio/longo prazo, de acordo com o presente conhecimento cient√≠fico sobre a tecnologia¬†5G, esta n√£o prejudica a sa√∫de dos humanos. H√° v√°rios estudos ¬†j√° realizados que apontam nesse sentido.
_______________________________
Nota editorial:¬†este conte√∫do foi selecionado pelo Pol√≠grafo¬†no √¢mbito de uma parceria de¬†fact-checking¬†com o Facebook, destinada a avaliar a veracidade das informa√ß√µes que circulam nessa rede social.
Na¬† escala de avalia√ß√£o do Facebook ,¬†este conte√∫do √©:
Falso:¬†as principais alega√ß√µes dos conte√∫dos s√£o factualmente imprecisas; geralmente, esta op√ß√£o corresponde √†s classifica√ß√µes "Falso" ou "Maioritariamente falso" nos¬†sites¬†de verificadores de factos.
Na¬† escala de avalia√ß√£o do Pol√≠grafo ,¬†este conte√∫do √©:
Notifica√ß√µes

artHead: Image of a Muslim boy, Rizwan, who had died after being beaten up by Tanda (UP) Police for violating the lockdown restrictions mandated due to COVID-19 spread.
exp: Ambedkarnagar district Police clarified that, in their investigation, they have found that Rizwan was not beaten by the Police. Also, the Police has said that, in the postmortem report, it was mentioned that the deceased had an infection in lungs & heart and injuries due to falling from a motorcycle, which was confirmed by a local doctor.

artHead: The photo of a vaccine for canine coronavirus proves that a vaccine exists for the novel coronavirus.
exp: The photo shows a vaccine for the canine coronavirus, which is not the same virus affecting humans around the world.
articleContent:
Facebook Users Wrongly Tie Dog Vaccine to Novel Coronavirus
April 22, 2020
Quick Take
A viral image on Facebook falsely suggests a vaccine exists for the novel coronavirus by referencing a photo of a vaccine for a coronavirus that infects dogs. The two viruses are not the same.
Full Story¬†
Facebook users are spreading a photo of a vaccine for canine coronavirus to wrongly suggest that a vaccine exists for the novel coronavirus now infecting humans around the world.
‚ÄúNow this was 2001 tell me why 19 years later they say there is no vaccine,‚Äù text in the viral image reads .
The image was shared in various corners of Facebook, including in a group dedicated to the QAnon conspiracy theory . One user‚Äôs popular post claimed that a ‚ÄúCORONA VIRUS VACCINE EXIST SINCE 2001‚Ä≥ and ‚ÄúWE ARE BEING PLAYED BY THOSE ON THE TOP.‚Äù
But the vaccine label in the photo clearly states ‚ÄúCanine Coronavirus Vaccine.‚Äù
Like other instances of misinformation that have appeared since the outbreak began, the posts advance a false claim that centers on the term ‚Äúcoronavirus.‚Äù The term refers to a family of viruses, but they‚Äôre not all the same.
The novel coronavirus , or SARS-CoV-2 ‚Äî which causes COVID-19 ‚Äî was first reported in China in late 2019.
The product in the viral photo is Nobivac 1-Cv , a vaccine sold by a subsidiary of Merck & Co. It protects dogs from the canine coronavirus , or CCV, a virus that typically causes a mild gastroenteritis, or inflammation in the intestines, in infected dogs. It was first identified in 1971.
As we wrote when debunking similar posts dealing with a vaccine for cows, experts say it is not safe for humans to attempt to vaccinate themselves with animal vaccines.
Editor‚Äôs note: FactCheck.org is one of several organizations¬† working with Facebook ¬†to debunk misinformation shared on social media. Our previous stories can be found¬† here .
Sources

artHead: Three photos showing dozens of body bags have been shared thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook which claim they show the bodies of COVID-19 victims in Pakistan.
exp: The claim is false; the photos in fact show covered corpses in Pakistan after a severe heatwave in 2015 that left hundreds dead.
articleContent:
These photos show victims of a deadly heatwave in 2015 that killed hundreds in Pakistan
Email
Published on Wednesday 29 April 2020 At 14:00
Three photos showing dozens of body bags have been shared thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook which claim¬†they show the bodies of COVID-19 victims in Pakistan. The claim is false; the photos in fact show covered corpses in Pakistan after a severe heatwave in 2015 that left hundreds dead.
The photos were shared more than 3,800 times after being published on Facebook here on April 20, 2020.
The post‚Äôs Chinese caption translates to English as: ‚ÄúPakistan's coronavirus epidemic, corpses everywhere, sad to see Amitabha (pray emoji)‚Äù.
‚Äú Amitabha ‚Äù refers to a prominent buddha in east Asian Buddhism.
Below is a screenshot of the misleading Facebook post:
Screenshot of misleading Facebook post
The photos were also shared alongside a similar claim¬†on Facebook here and here .
The claim is false.¬†
A reverse Google image search found the first two pictures were taken by an AFP photographer after a deadly heatwave in June 2015, almost five years before the COVID-19 pandemic. The photos were published on AFP forum here and here .
The images show charity workers burying and offering funeral prayers for unclaimed victims of the extreme temperature in the Pakistani city of Karachi on June 26, 2015. At least 1,000 people were killed by the heat, AFP reported at the time.
Below is a side-by-side comparison of two of the pictures in the misleading Facebook post (L) and the original AFP photographs (R):
Side-by-side comparison of the picture in the misleading Facebook post (L) and the original AFP photograph (R)
Side-by-side comparison of the picture in the misleading Facebook post (L) and the original AFP photograph (R)
A reverse image search found the third photo shared in the misleading Facebook posts was published by the European Pressphoto Agency (EPA) on June 22, 2015.
Below is a side-by-side comparison of the picture from the misleading Facebook post (L) and the original EPA photograph (R):
Side-by-side comparison of the picture from the misleading Facebook post (L) and the original EPA photograph (R)
The photograph‚Äôs caption reads: ‚ÄúRescue workers move the bodies of the victims of heatwave at a mortuary in Karachi, Pakistan, 22 June 2015. The death toll from a heatwave in Pakistan climbed to nearly 150 on 22 June, health officials said.
